rules: Rule1: Either a doctor has access to patient records or a nurse has access to patient records.
Rule2: Either the AI model diagnoses a ransomware infection or the response team confirms a ransomware outbreak.
Rule3: Under the condition that the response team confirms a ransomware outbreak, the compliance officer does not grant an exemption.
Rule4: If the dashboard monitors show access attempts, then the dashboard displays a warning about an unauthorized attempt.
Rule5: If a nurse has access to patient records, then the organization is compliant with HIPAA.
Rule6: Either the admin reviewed the logs, or, if it is not the case that a doctor having access to patient records implies HIPAA compliance for the organization, then the system triggers an alert.
Rule7: Either the admin contacted support, or the admin did not review the logs.
Rule8: Under the condition that the IDS generates a report on the incident, the security manager does not permit an override.
Rule9: If it is not the case that a doctor having access to patient records implies HIPAA compliance for the organization, then the antivirus initiates a scan on the endpoints.
Rule10: If it is not the case that a doctor having access to patient records implies HIPAA compliance for the organization, then the quarantine system isolates the device.
Rule11: If it is not the case that the AI model diagnosing a ransomware infection implies that the compliance officer does not grant an exemption, then management issues a denial.
Rule12: If it is not the case that the AI model diagnosing a ransomware infection implies that the compliance officer does not grant an exemption, then management does not issue a denial.

Rule13: If it is not the case that either the CISO approves the emergency patch procedure or, if it is not the case that a doctor having access to patient records implies HIPAA compliance for the organization, then the system triggers an alert, then the IT department delays the response.

Rule14: If it is not the case that the dashboard displaying a warning about an unauthorized attempt implies that either the SOC analyst escalates the alert or, whenever a device connection requires authorization, the IT department does not delay the response, then the NOC technician acknowledges the alert.

Rule15: If it is not the case that the dashboard displaying a warning about an unauthorized attempt implies that either the SOC analyst escalates the alert or, whenever a device connection requires authorization, the IT department does not delay the response, then the NOC technician does not acknowledge the alert.
Rule16: If it is not the case that the antivirus initiating a scan on the endpoints implies the system triggers an alert, then the antivirus does not update its signatures.
Rule17: If it is not the case that the quarantine system isolating the device implies the system triggers an alert, then the security manager permits an override.
Rule18: If it is not the case that the IDS detecting an anomaly in the clinic network implies it generates a report on the incident, then the compliance officer grants an exemption.

Rule19: If it is not the case that the condition "it is not the case that the antivirus initiating a scan on the endpoints implies the system triggers an alert" implies the antivirus updates its signatures, then the IT staff rolls back the update.

Rule20: If it is not the case that the condition "it is not the case that the antivirus initiating a scan on the endpoints implies the system triggers an alert" implies the antivirus updates its signatures, then the IT staff does not roll back the update.
facts: Fact1: The device connection requires authorization.
Fact2: The dashboard monitors show access attempts.
Fact3: The IDS detects an anomaly in the clinic network.
Fact4: The CISO does not approve the emergency patch procedure.
Fact5: The SOC analyst does not escalate the alert.
Fact6: The system does not trigger an alert.
Fact7: The admin did not contact support.

question: The organization is compliant with HIPAA.
